column10: b"b' hey @bakercp
column11: not sure if this is the correct place to be asking this but
column12: i recently built a project for oF that had to support iPad 3 (retina) and iPad 2. for this it was very useful to be able to set the DPI that the font was rendered and then drawn at
column13: while leaving the screen units the same. ie
column14: the point resolution of the screen was always 1024x768 but on ipad 3 there were four pixels to every point
column15: and the font knew to draw itself by scaling the underlying textures to 50% to make this work.. i hope you follow! anyway it would be good to make that work in the new ofFont.  also what would be good is easy crisp fonts at low point sizes. with ofTrueTypeFont i made a number of hacks to achieve multi-line 12 point Helvetica rendering without artefacts: 1. round the line height to whole number (force y to integer)2. force the glyphs to be drawn at integer pixel locations (force x to integer)'"

b"b' of*: pressedKeys accumulate in special cases'"
b'b\' In some cases
column11: when modifier keys are used
column12: the pressedKeys set will accumulate keys. This happens because "modifier-up" messages are not sent in the same way as normal and special keys. To test
column13: watch the size of the pressedKeys: Press a modifier key and a normal key -say ctrl-a.  If the \\\'a\\\' is lifted first
column14: then the modified-a key int is removed from the pressedKeys set.  If CTRL is released before the \\\'a\\\'
column15: then the non-modified-a key-up int is sent
column16: and it is not erased from the pressedKeys set.  If this is repeated with different modifier+key downs / ups the accumulation occurs. Ultimately
column17: there needs to be better handling of modifier keys.  Perhaps there is a way to use the modifier masks keep track of modifier keys with a call to glutGetModifiers() in the keyboard_cb and keyboard_up_cb static methods? It looks like progress has been made toward this in ofConstants.h But it seems to have stopped there. I\\\'m happy to work on this -any suggestions on a strategy?  Perhaps this is already being addressed of 007?\''

column10: b"b' Perhaps this is obvious
column11: but this issue ultimately stems from the fact that GLUT does not deliver stand-alone modifier  events like Java (or other windowing systems)
column12: making it difficult to keep track of such things ... Here is an interesting post on the topic. url '"

column10: b"b' is this being addressed by url  ?'"
b'b\' Hi bilderbuchi -yes that modification is on the right track
column11: but it probably won\\\'t work as expected because glutGetModifiers() wants to be called in the keyboard_cb and keyboard_up_cb methods (at least from my testing on OSX).  It will dump lots of warnings that look something like:  gameoverhack\\\'s 807 pull request would be a very useful set of methods
column12: but instead of calling the calling glutGetModifiers() it should probably work by checking "pressedKeys" set with a call that looks like: etc. Thus
column13: for this to really work
column14: there needs to be better modifier bookkeeping at the core site of the original glut callback. As I said
column15: I\\\'m quite interested in getting this working and am happy to tackle it.  Do you know if there are any other forks addressing the issue? -just copied some of these thoughts over to #807\''

column10: b'b" I\'m not aware of other work on that
column11: but if gameoverhack\'s PR addresses at least part of the issue
column12: I think it\'s best to comment there on how the  could be improved. Then all the work on this kind of issue is kept in one place. PR\'s are there to be discussed
column13: so don\'t be shy. ;-) I will drop a link to this issue there
column14: in any case."'

column10: b'b" I spent quite a while on this one and am beginning to wonder if it is possible to accurately keep track of keys via the pressedKeys set strategy.  Ultimately the problem lies in the fact that GLUT is only delivering ascii coded values via it\'s keyboard callbacks.  For any given physical key
column11: these singular ascii values can be changed by modifier keys (like ctrl)
column12: meaning that in some situations (as described above ctrl+a
column13: then release ctrl
column14: then release a)
column15: keeping a simple list of ascii coded values will lead to unpredictable results -basically all keyDowns are not guaranteed to have a matching keyUp.  The ideal ways to keep track of pressedKeys is to have a keyEvent system that records keyboard activity based on physical keyCodes -or at least some sense of VirtualKeys (i.e. VK_LEFT
column16: etc).  Examples include Java\'s [KeyEvent]url  system or a Javascript strategy like [this]url If we had input events at this level
column17: it would also easily take care of issue here #807.  In the mean-time
column18: you can check out my proposed solution to keymodifier issue over at issue #807.  At least it is possible to have a robust solution to that problem."'

column10: b"b' closing this issue since GLUT is not our primary windowing system anymore.'"
b"b' This is still an issue w/ GLFW'"

b'b" Just tested this again.  Keep an eye on the pressedKeys set. Press CTRL-a. Then lift the CTRL and keep a held. then release a. Then you\'ll still have a key in the pressed keys set. To free it again
column11: Press CTRL-a then release a
column12: then release CTRL."'

b"b' found one possible cause of the slow down you are describing @chrisoshea in this line.url  if a video size is bigger then 1024 then it will recreate the texture on every frame.but this is only if its bigger and 1024x768 should have been fine. not sure where this 1024 limitation came from..? maybe the maximum texture size on the old iphone which was 1024x1024...but pretty sure all the new iphone support up to 2048x2048 now. **EDIT**my bad

column11: based on an assumed range of [0
column12: 1]. with fmod expecting [-1

b"b' the first hurdle with the current ofFbo implementation was to get around this error log message
column11: FRAMEBUFFER_UNSUPPORTED by disabling the stencil buffer
column12: which is set to true by default
column13: got the fbo working again.   = false; think this issue is attributed to this note on PowerVR SGX [url In iOS 4.0 and later
column14: separate stencil buffers are not supported. Use a combined  buffer  although im not sure what is meant by combining the depth and stencil buffer.  any ideas @arturoc @ofTheo @obviousjim?'"

column10: b'b" okay I think I have a fix for this. the above fix by @julapy get the fbo loading.  the stretch issues are caused by two things:1) iOS defaults to GL_TEXTURE_2D but the tex coords are not being correctly set ( tex_t and tex_u are set to 1.0 )  This is actually a non iOS bug if you try and use GL_TEXTURE_2D in desktop OF with an FBO it will look strange. 2) in ofFbo::bind the fbo accounts for the iphone\'s orientation which I think means its being accounted for twice.  Fix:1) calculate the tex_t and tex_u in ofFbo::getTextureReference 2) Set the orientation to OF_ORIENTATION_DEFAULT for iOS builds in ofFbo::begin()"'
b"b' @ofTheo @julapy thanks for getting this working guys! '"

column12: also. My preference would be for removing the int volume setting entirely and just having 0..1 as per #375.'"

column10: b"b' yes if we are going to break it anyway i would say that the float option only seems the best
column11: 0..255 is super weird'"

column10: b'b" it\'s not actually going to break
column11: for most people.  the quicktime code currently passes the value unmodified through to SetMovieVolume()
column12: which has a range of 0..255. so when people are currently saying (100) they\'re only getting 40% volume. there was no clamping on this value. the linux code currently converts to a float 0..1 by clamping to 0..10 then dividing by 10."'

column10: b"b' @ofTheo @ofZach is this merge-worthy?'"

b'b" I\'m a bit nervous about this one for some reason :) setVolumef just sort of feels weird  I wish we got it right as normalized values the firs time round.  has it been tested on the different platforms ? "'
b'b" @ofTheo But we didn\'t get it right
column11: it never has been right.  The [documentation]url  says setVolume takes 0..100. The ofVideoPlayer class [passes the volume unchanged through to the player pointer]url For QuickTime
column12: this calls the underlying [QuickTime function SetMovieVolume]url  which actually accepts AFAICT 0..255. Documentation here (google [quicktime setMovieVolume MoviesTask site:]url  seems to hint 0..255 or 0..1
column13: but is sparse and contradictory. Consensus seems 0..255 is correct. No-one mentions 0..100. And the Linux implementation is just weird and incompatible: it has an effective range of 0..10: [passes value unchanged]url  -In any case
column14: does anyone aside from Theo think that 0..1 is weird for a volume call? To me 0..1 is totally natural
column15: it\'s 0..100 or 0..255 that\'s weird."'

column10: b'b" @julapy
column11: this is an issue for me with an app i\'m working on right now. you\'ve done iOS programming using native GUI (Objective-C
column12: UITableViewController...) right? yes in theory glScalef() does this fine
column13: but if i use ofGetWidth() with pixel offsets to position things relative to the screen (which I do) this doesn\'t work. instead i have to either hard code 1024x768 everywhere (which is bad) or pass around a global struct storing these things (which is less bad but still non-ideal). plus
column14: touch arguments assume 2048x1536
column15: so i\'m going to have to go and do everywhere which is a pain. i don\'t actually own a retina ipad so i\'m relying on a client on the other side of the English Channel to debug it for me. @bilderbuchi the way iOS does things internally is actually quite neat. they redefine \'pixel\' as \'point\' and then any GUI that you layout on a non-retina screen just works without changing a single constant on a retina screen
column16: ie in retina each pixel is in fact 0.5 \'points\' wide. it seems weird but in practise it\'s brilliant
column17: with 0 effort you get double the resolution and you don\'t actually have to own a retina device to know that your code will work fine."'

column10: b'b\' I\\\'ve been working on a few iOS projects and handling retina is a pain. Lots of custom code handling -retina situations
column11: adapting to what  reports
column12: handling @2x res images.... Having something to handle this elegantly would be great.  I totally vote for @ofTheo\\\'s: and making pixelDensity affect all the units across OF: ofFBOs
column13: ofTTF
column14: ofTouchEvents
column15: ofDrawBitmapString
column16: etc...  I would also be inclined on setting those automatically on each platform; Say
column17: on a retina iPhone
column18: there are 960 x 640 pixels on screen
column19: but those pixels are so small that it almost makes no sense to treat them as such (for example
column20: using ofDrawBitmapString draws such small type that is almost unreadable). I think OF should automatically set the pixelDensity given the device capabilities
column21: but  should report always 480 x 320. OF would handle internally what happens at draw time
column22: so ofRect(0
column25: 10) would draw a 20 x 20 pixel rect in reality
column26: but the user wouldn\\\'t need to handle that... Got some doubts though
column27: it might be  how to proceed for a few elements ( videoGrabbers come to mind; let\\\'s say we are on PixelDensity == 2
column28: does requesting a 640 x 480 connect to the device @ 1280 x 960? ) Maybe a solution would be two keep two different nomenclatures in all methods that accept width & height

column30: and "pixels" to anything related to external devices like grabbers
column31: etc... otherwise it might be hard to guess which units to use in every situation\''

openFrameworks	1470	closed	28	bakercp	2012-08-08 11:41:24	251.97			+1	b'b" Hey @underdoeg I\'\'ve spent some time with this and have a few initial thoughts:Is there a way to move away from the \\\\* pointer style for  ?  It seems to mix both raw and (via  ).  It seems that all of them could be replaced with  .  The only hangup I found is when the window itself calls the window manager to activate the current window using the argument.  That could be fixed via a friend class setup.  Another option would be to get rid of the default constructor on and use something like to keep it all raw-pointer free.  Maybe it\'s not a big deal, but it seems that we need to do one or the other and not mix.  Then in the destructor for we just need to make sure that the window manager and glfw both are notified and everything is destroyed in the correct order ... (perhaps not trivial :)).I\'m wondering if our ofEvents need to have a base field with a window id (ideally just an unsigned int)?  I\'m imagining that you could add (referring to the main class as a listener to the main window, if the main window class implemented / extended the listener).  In such a case, it would be important to know where various events were coming from.With GLFW, we can get rid of the bug-prone #652 , although with GLFW it might stay updated a little better ... or maybe not.  Is there an easy way that we could bypass that functionality when using the glfw window?  It seems like you might just look at the current window and see if it is glfw.Fullscreen it looks like this is still not implemented on os x and will need to be custom platform-specific code, unless we destroy and create the new windows each time the is changed?  Any idea why glfw doesn\'t implement this internally?  It seems like a pretty basic thing ... ? More thoughts over the next few days. Overall, this is a very exciting (and much needed) departure from GLUT.  Even if it didn\'t offer multiple windows it would be an upgrade!"'

I\'ll just post my initial thoughts right now:Sure we could use an ofWindowPtr somehow. (I\'m not going into all the technical problems now.) What is your main reason for this? Or are you rather concerned that a user might accidentally keep an ofWindow\\\\* that actually points to a destroyed window?I have created a base class ofWindowEvent for that purpose that has a pointer to the ofWindow that is sending the event. openFrameworks	1470	closed	30	bakercp	2012-08-08 11:41:24	529.47		+1		b'b\' I\\\'ve continued to spend more time on this today and have a few discussion questions / propositions, particularly related to input events.1. the event has traditionally reported both the drag position AND the (supposed) button that is being pressed to cause the "move" to become a "drag".  But, in the current paradigm, that single number does not completely describe the situation of multiple buttons being pressed, or pressed and released in succession.  Instead, if you really want to know which buttons are being pressed, you must call with an optional argument to query a specific button.  GLFW (like many windowing systems) does not report "drag" events, but rather reports mouse movement and lets the user check to see if any mouse button is pressed.  Thus, instead of making documentation caveats about what the "button" in the drag function actually means, I\\\'d propose removing the "button" argument from the drag function and encouraging the use of to discover the true nature of the buttons being pressed.2. Unified touch / mouse and "pointer" events.  This one may be more controversial, but I would propose that we take the opportunity to unite touch and mouse events into a single event.  Pointer is the term used by Microsoft and others to describe "pointing" input devices like touches, mice, trackballs, pens, etc.  While many of the parameters like "touch size" and "pressure" would simply be set to default static values for a mouse event (for instance), it would offer more flexibility for guis, etc.  Within the there would be an enum that described the device "type" (mouse, touch, pen, etc).  GLFW has plans to incorporate touch events in the 3.0 roadmap, and most modern operating systems now support touch events to varying degrees.  This would also help us move toward making ios apps look a little more like desktop apps, and would also allow easy integration with addons like  , TUIO, and addons that attempt to leverage the OSX multitouch private framework.3. I\\\'d propose starting an official openFrameworks branch for this so that it is easy for people to start testing this very thoroughly.  I\\\'d also propose going GLUT free on that test branch rather than having both windowing systems living side by side (which I know was @underdoeg original intent). I\\\'m pushing a bunch of updates, additions and proposals over to @underdoeg tomorrow for discussion.  @kylemcdonald perhaps we can talk about some of this in the IRC meetup tomorrow?\''
openFrameworks	1470	closed	31	ofZach	2012-08-08 11:41:24	488.48	+1			b'b" quickly, I\'m not a huge fan of (1) since it seems sort of counter intuitive to me.  It probably makes sense to look at a majority of cross platform window systems (ie, url  and see what they do.  To be honest, I haven\'t seen that many mouseMoved only window systems, but maybe I haven\'t seen that many window systems :)  curious what other people think ? but 2 would make a lot of sense and it\'s something that\'s been discussed before .  I would support very much.  ofPointer is kind of an easily misleading name however, since pointer / ptr has so much c++ connotation.  Also, we sort of already have this with the touch event in ofEvents:  so it might just be a matter of finding a way to make the mouse events mesh better with the touch events.  a branch for this kind of development sounds good to me...."'
openFrameworks	1470	closed	32	underdoeg	2012-08-08 11:41:24	50.25			+1	b'b\' I also feel like 1 is a little counter intuitive. But it sure makes sense and that is why all window managers implement it in that way. But on the other hand with OF we\\\'re trying to simplify stuff (otherwise you could just use glfw directly...) I feel like it is always some sort of balancing act between simplicity and the "correct" way to do things. I like the approach to have the most common usage wrapped up as easily as possible and if you need special functionality you can get it by a little digging into the more hidden functions. But about the dragging and mouse pressed argument in general. What if mouse pressed was some sort of specialized vector? so you\\\'d have a syntax like  (0) //button  0 is pressed or that could also be (OF_MOUSE_BUTTON_LEFT)  2 absolutely needs to be done in the near future IMO 3 With this multiwindow branch we could go two ways. a) to simply remove GLUT and replace with GLFW without touching the general syntax as much as possible. That\\\'s what I tried to do so far and in this case I don\\\'t mind having GLUT still in there as an option. or b) to rethink how input events, and other window events are handled and do it in a smarter way. But that probably leads to signficant API changes and may even result in compatibility issues with older apps. When I started the branch, I would have loved to do b) straight away but I thought the proper way would probably be to do a) first and when glfw if properly within OF and everything works as before, we can move to b).  But I also think we should have a branch on the official OF repo.\''

column13: M3 (experimental)new postprocessing steps: Debonevastly improved IFC (Industry Foundation Classes) supportintroduced API to query importer meta information (such as supported   format versions
column14: full name

column10: b"b' ofDisableAlphaBlending() does not have effect on (..)When AA is enabled
column11: the font has a smooth border
column12: and it is blended with the background. At the border of the font
column13: some color from the background is mixed with font color.The problem appears when we do not want to get color from the background mixed with font color
column14: as the text image will be further blended with other images. Alpha blending should be disabled when the font is drawn. But the font edge looks the same
column15: with a color cast from background at the border
column16: regardless if alpha blending is enabled or not.Setup:loadFont is called with default params except for font path and size. (border is false)Image has 4 channels. Background can be set to black (0

column10: b'b\' OK.  I did some work on this.  My tests project / files and output is here: url  Basically
column11: the mis-colored anti-aliasing you are getting is due to an issue with blending on FBOs where it takes the cast of the ofClear color (i.e. black in your examples) EVEN if the opacity was 0. You can test this by changing your clear color to say - .  This will result in a green cast. This issue also affects anti-aliased lines on an FBO
column12: etc. I am not sure how to "fix" (or even if it should be considered a bug or just normal opengl behavior). To prevent it from happening
column13: just make sure your clear color is white with 0 opacity
column14: i.e.  . @bogru -you do this initially when you clear your FBO on creation
column15: but then you clear with non-white colors elsewhere. Perhaps an opengl / fbo expert could weigh in on this blending behavior?  There are lots of images in my linked project above. Regarding the lack of changes associated with calling alphablend
column16: etc with fonts
column17: I believe alpha blending is forced on during rendering for fonts because without it
column18: all anti aliasing / hinting disappears resulting in blocky fonts.\''

column10: b'b\' I think it is normal to have a color cast
column11: (even is opacity is 0 inbackground image
column12: as alpha from drawn  will be used forblending)
column13: if we have alpha blending. But if there is no alpha blending
column14: the values from the drawn element should not be altered by values inbackground. "Regarding the lack of changes associated with calling alphablend
column15: etc withfonts
column16: I believe alpha blending is forced on during rendering for fontsbecause without it
column17: all anti aliasing / hinting disappears resulting inblocky fonts."It is not necessary to disappear. At the border it is enough to havedecreased alpha (as it is now with AA)
column18: and it will blend nicely withwhatever background will be further used. Moreover
column19: it is not correct
column20: ifalpha blending is disabled
column21: to have alpha blending. (ie alter the rgbvalues depending on background and alpha) The "solution" with white background is not acceptable
column22: as the white willstill be blended into font color at the borders of the font. Please examinepixel values. Thank you for your work and interest

column10: b'b\' So we shouldn\\\'t be setting the orientation programmatically at the java level. It causes all kinds of problems.  We should be setting the orientation in the manifest.  Please check what you have listed in the activity section for the screenOrientation as it should be one of the following. Also we have to change the orientation at the CPP level to change the coordinate system
column11: you should use the  ofSetOrientation() call in your CPP to manage the orientation of the objects you are drawing on the screen.  android:screenOrientation=["unspecified" | "user" | "behind" |             "landscape" | "portrait" |             "reverseLandscape" | "reversePortrait" |             "sensorLandscape" | "sensorPortrait" |             "sensor" | "fullSensor" | "nosensor"] \''

Still buggy: if you don\\\'t specify any orientation with ofSetOrientation()The orientation will be in locked in Portrait after pause and resume
column12: no matter what you specified in the manifest.So it might be a problem if you want to use Sensor oriented app. Best Regards
column13: Thomas\''

column10: b'b" OK we might need an event that gets tossed down from the JAVA to the CPP to handle screen rotations.  So currently in the CPP if ofSetOrientation(fooBar)  isn\'t called it defaults to OF_ORIENTATION_DEFAULT and that gets set at Java_cc_openframeworks_OFAndroid_onSurfaceCreated() in .  In the JAVA we never actually make the call to CPP to change the oF orientation we just setup the Activity in  using the setScreenOrientation(int orientation) method.  So I guess the problem is that when we change the Orientation of the Activity in the JAVA layer it is never getting communicated to the CPP layer. "'
b'b" ok
column11: that fixes it
column12: now if you set the orientation from the manifest it\'ll work even when resuming and if you set the orientation programmatically it\'ll work and stay in that after resuming too. also fixes when no orientation is set"'

column10: b"b' Closed by #1776 '"
b"b' Retire ofxThreadedImageLoader due to bad memory management and lack of thread control'"

b"b' I did a code analysis and set this class to use a notify thread shceme.  After doing this I realized the memory management scheme here is inherently flawed since the addon changes memory allocated in the main class without a lock.  This addon as it stands now is dangerous. Issues:Hungry threads that do not sleep
column11: eats up system resources.update() routine changes ofImage memory without any lock to data object. A generalized image loading manager should be built that controls and locks its own memory objects.  A on-demand image load can be added as well as a timeout purge.  I will work on this in the future.'"

column10: b'b" I brought up your second point with @arturoc a while ago and he seemed quite convinced that it wasn\'t a problem. I\'ve been extremely dubious but in practise
column11: since the actually call to ofImage::update() to update the pixels happens in the main thread
column12: i haven\'t seen any issues (I\'m not saying there aren\'t any
column13: rather that in fairly heavy practise they haven\'t shown up yet). I have a new version of ofxThreadedImageLoader that fixes a bunch of other locking issues though
column14: doesn\'t eat CPU and has better behaviour on failure
column15: also with a cancel ability. Haven\'t got around to making a PR with it yet."'

column10: b'b" He is probably correct in a simple situation where the only data accessing is in main thread update() draw() but overall I see this as bad software design.  I\'m curious to see your repo once made PR."'

b'b" don\'t remember exactly what we were talking about damian but i think it was about if 2 threads can access the same memory area at the same time even for writing without making the app crash? what they actually can
column11: a seg fault only happens when a program access memory that it\'s not reserved to it by the OS then the OS stops it\'s execution to avoid security problems. anyway in this case the access from the thread to the image is safe as long as you don\'t try to access the pixels without checking isAllocated first
column12: since the image is being created in the thread and only being put in the loaded queue once it\'s loaded using locks
column13: but yes the structure is kind of weird having the queues as public for example
column14: and the fact that it\'s not sleeping is also bad
column15: i would use a poco condition to signal the thread where there\'s something in the queue to be processed
column16: that way the thread won\'t run at all unless it has something to do"'

column10: b'b" It\'s not about segfaults... the reason why I feel like this is  code is mainly not because of what it does now
column11: but because of changes someone might make in the future. As long as any programmer working on the class knows that this is safe because the call to ofImage::update() is forced to happen in the main thread because it waits for the event
column12: and as long as ofImage isn\'t restructured in a way that makes a call to loadImage() no longer intrinsically thread-safe wrt the values of isAllocated
column13: width and height
column14: then this will continue to be bad design.  Understanding why and how not break this requires a pretty thorough knowledge of the ofImage internals and multithreaded programming
column15: as well as recognizing the subtletly of the update call only happening in the main thread. But there\'s no comments in the class that properly explain this for future developers
column16: and there\'s no guarantee that something in ofImage might change behind your back in the meantime which makes this system no longer safe. The main issue I have in trusting this code as it stands is that I don\'t have any proof that calling loadImage()/update() is intrinsically threadsafe wrt the values of isAllocated
column17: width and height
column18: and certainly I have no proof that this won\'t change in the future."'

column10: b'b" I agree the with the above. It\'s poor design to have assumptions for one class based on functionality external to the class. Programming should be modular and decoupled. "'

b'b" Pull request #1820 has been submitted.While in the grand scheme I have issues with the update scheme (discussed above) we had multiple projects dependent on the ofxThreadedImageLoader working better.  I moved to a  method and have tested rather thoroughly (although I have not done url loading). The only caveat is that when large numbers of image load requests are made at a time (in our case 150)
column11: subsequent updates() can take a while while the ofImage resources are copied over.  A fix would be to do something like only 5ms of processing per update or 5 images per update
column12: etc
column13: but we didn\'t get around to implementing this."'

column10: b"b' now that #1820 has been merged I guess we can close this issue?'"
b"b' yes
column11: thanks'"

column16: url  i spent something like half a day trying to work out why my model was rendering differently in OF.the model i created was also broken down into separate mesh so i could address them separately and manipulate them in OF but optimisation was merging the meshes and that resulted in more pulling of hair.anyway... i guess optimising the model is all well and good and it does save on memory

column10: b'b" add setter for OpenAL\'s distance model in ofxOpenALSoundPlayer"'
b'b\' This adds a simple feature to the ofxOpenALSoundPlayer on ios
column11: requested in issue #1322 and added to the 0.8.0 milestone list. This code just adds a wrapper for the setter. In addition
column12: there\\\'s a little note in the header explaining what the "distance model" means
column13: what the default one is (as per the OpenAL spec)
column14: and calls attention to the AL_LINEAR_DISTANCE_CLAMPED which is _not_ the default
column15: but is perhaps more intuitive (again
column16: see #1322). Also
column17: I\\\'ve added a minimal demonstration of the new functionality to the OpenAL example
column18: similar to @armadillu\\\'s original demonstration. Let me know if you\\\'d like that to be a separate PR. I\\\'m against making it the default
column19: as suggested
column20: but I _do_ personally think that AL_LINEAR_DISTANCE_CLAMPED acts more like what I\\\'d expect. Summoning @ofTheo and @julapy\''

column10: b"b' cool!'"

column10: b"b' Feature programmable GL texture mipmaps'"

column11: but the new openGL core API for mipmaps
column12: since gluBuild2DMipmaps is deprecated (and will
column13: for example
column14: disappear from the OS X 10.9 SDK)see: url  Since ofTexture mipmaps would also affect ofFbo if mipmaps were switched on my default i thought it sensible to let the user decide when to create mipmaps (and when to update their mipmaps)
column15: so mipmaps are not generated by default.  Since this adds a new method to the API i\'d be curious to hear everyone\'s opinion on how best to include mipmapping (and how much of the internals to expose). By default
column16: this sets the  filters for the texture it affects to: Also
column17: and  are global functions
column18: but they _assume a current texture target to be bound_. That is most likely asking for trouble with the programmable GL renderer
column19: and makes reading code difficult and might better be deprecated
column20: IMHO."'

column10: b"b' @tgfrerer do you think you could pull in the current master branch so we can see a clearer diff?  I think the option for mipmaps in general would be much appreciated. Right now you can have mipmaps with the regular renderer but only if you are doing compressed textures. This is an arbitrary constraint and I think having that separated from the texture compression on regular OpenGL would be good to do.  I think a general ofTexture::setMipMaps(bool bTrue) ( For both programmable and non-programble ) would be a good approach. You would call that before loadData.  Then you could set the min and mag filters as desired. Does that make sense? '"
b'b" Awww
column11: I\'ve tried to consolidate the versions
column12: and it\'s quite a mess
column13: so much so
column14: that i\'m tempted to abandon this PR and start a fresh one based on current master once i\'ve got more time. agreed
column15: there is no reason to link texture compression with mipmaps these lines in ofTexture could do with a bit of untangling although it is fairly easy to get compressed textures going with the programmable GL renderer currently
column16: using the right internal GL format settings for ofTexture
column17: so i\'d keep this for a little later... As for ofTexture::setMipmaps i wonder if it weren\'t better to generate mipmaps independently of loading the texture there might be cases where you might want to separate loading data from generating the mipmap (if only for workload balancing) and i\'d prefer it to be a command (as in generateMipmap() where i know that this means actual work is being enqueued to the GPU) to an opaque state change (where i\'m not sure when work happens). What do you think?"'

column10: b'b"   allows you to cast an ofPtr from its parent type to one of its derived types
column11: just like (which is the preferred c++ style of dynamic pointer casting) does for raw pointers. was an internal flag that some c++11 implementations used to signal that the shared ptr was going to be re-cast
column12: and this is where it gets ugly
column13: since some  used this flags
column14: some didn\'t
column15: and ofPtr
column16: being essentially a fa\\xc3\\xa7ade around shared_ptr had to take all this into account.  in the short term
column17: i\'d suggest taking out the dynamic_pointer_cast functionality from ofPtr
column18: since it does more bad than good
column19: there real-life use-cases are rare and far-between
column20: and it\'s proved being a maintainability nightmare. in the long term
column21: i\'d suggest deprecating ofPtr in favour of shared_ptr and unique_ptr
column22: since that will also give us more compatibility towards other libraries. "'

column10: b"b' images / textures inside an ofCamera flipped in 0.8.0'"

b"b' When drawing an image inside a camera in the current develop the image is drawn with the texture inverted.  In some ways it looks better now because the image is being drawn correctly in terms of up but as its the exact opposite of how this used to work
column11: it will break any project doing textures inside a camera view. Taking an 0.7.3/0.7.4 project and porting it to 0.8.0 results in images being drawn upside down.  0.7.3: ![screen shot 2013-07-29 at 11 29 30 am]url  0.8.0: ![screen shot 2013-07-29 at 11 32 21 am]url  Here is test code for the two images based on the imageLoader example. '"

column10: b"b' possibly related to #1976 '"

b'b" there\'s now a check for ofIsVFlipped that is checked by ofTexture so anything that draws inside a camera (or if setupPerspective is set without vflip) using textures draws correctly the current changes to ofCamera taking into account orientation will break any corrections done manually to ofCamera to compensate for the orientation anyway so i think it\'s a good time to fix this also even if it breaks some projects"'

b"b' glad it was intentional :) though I do worry about the MANY projects that might be broken by these changes.  Are we sure we want to break pretty much any project that uses ofCamera / ofEasyCam and ofImage / ofTexture?  I spent quite a bit of time trying to figure out the issue and it was not super clear to me why things had changed.I could imagine this being very frustrating to other users too. '"

b'b\' i just want to back @arturoc a little and agree that i\\\'d rather have new users less confused than worry about  users becoming a little more confused. we can always explain things in the changelog
column11: and even tweet about it if we get more than one bug report. but it\\\'s not good to have to tell people "hey
column12: ofCamera is weird
column13: that\\\'s just the way it is."\''

column10: b'b" i would have more doubts if this was the only change we had introduced in ofCamera but anyone using it in iOS or anything using ofSetOrientation will have to fix their projects and the fixes related to orientation are even harder to get right than this one
column11: so i think it\'s better to break this now than breaking it again in a couple of releases"'

column12: but still

column11: what i mean is not about this issue but something else we\'ve fixed in ofCamera: in iOS before if you were using a camera in lets say landscape you\'ll need to rotate the camera 90 degrees to fix the orientation not being taken into account by ofCamera. since we\'ve fixed that
column12: now every iOS app using ofCamera will be rotated by 90 degrees in landscape mode this also applies for any platform using ofSetOrientation
column13: i was just using iOS as an example cause that\'s the most probable case but any installation with the monitor in vertical using ofCamera will have the same problem so since people will need to fix applications using ofCamera anyway
column14: even if we don\'t include this
column15: i think it\'s a good time to include this too instead of breaking something in 0.8 and break it again later since the current behavior pre 0.8 is clearly wrong and at some point we\'ll want to fix it also to get the old behavior you can just set flipTexture to true in texData "'

column10: b'b" one other issue ( and I promise I\'m not just trying to be difficult :) if you look at the second image ( which is how it is currently in 0.8.0 )
column11: you\'ll notice that the anchorPercent is (0.5
column12: 1.0 )  That normally means
column13: the anchor is halfway in x and the bottom of the image in y.But because we are now flipping the texture ( compared to how it used to be )
column14: the anchor is incorrectly ( in terms of tex coords ) appearing to be 0.5
column15: 0.0 ( i.e. the top of the image ).  This is also a pretty big change / weird behavior and has the potential to confuse a lot of people. "'

column12: since the y coordinate in the screen grows from bottom to top the image anchor 0 is now at the bottom and 1 at the top. this are not texture coordinates but geometry related
column13: is the point in which transformations will be applied so i think they should behave the same as the coordinates of the 3d space. changing this to behave the opposite should be easy though
column14: so we can do it the other way around and put a comment on those methods specifying they are tex coords so should always be specified from top to bottom'"

column11: don\\\'t give up yet -i\\\'m on your side @ofTheo.1. it doesn\\\'t make sense for the meaning texture coordinates to change just because you\\\'re working in 3d. if the textures were "upside down" in 0.7.4 then the solution is to flip the entire ofCamera view. not jus the textures! (even though i\\\'m not familiar with iOS stuff but it sounds like there might be more going on there?)2. imagine that you write a shader outside an ofCamera. then you run it on a texture inside an ofCamera. now your calculations are being down upside-down

b'b" @kylemcdonald ofImage does the right thing now
column11: draws an image with the correct orientation. if you set a mesh with the texture coordinates as if the screen was setup the way OF does by default then you are going to get the image upside down
column12: but people used to work with the default openGL coordinate system (as ofCamera works) don\'t setup tex coordinates like that i\'ve heard several complains from people trying to teach openGL books using OF and they always find this kind of things problematic. if the coordinates are set so y grows from bottom to top things should work as with default openGL also if you want camera with -y as camera up you just need to call (true)"'

column10: b'b\' ok
column11: flipping the camera is not an option because it breaks everything for everyone. got it :) and catering to more people is good
column12: but i think that we should prioritize people coming from OF-2D into OF-3D over people who are reading opengl books. also
column13: i think it\\\'s better to not change behavior in a way that breaks things unless the solution is really "more correct"
column14: and here it\\\'s not obvious that one is "more correct"
column15: just that people from different background have different . the anchor thing is important too. instead of changing the behavior and making old projects "break"
column16: let\\\'s leave  a simple option that handles texture flipping and anchor flipping (even though y-axis flipping is left alone). it gives people flexibility without breaking things.\''

column10: b'b" also what changes inside ofCamera when drawing ofImage is actually the vertices of the quad to draw it with the correct orientation
column11: the tex coordinates remain the same so you won\'t have any problem with a shader. i\'ve done tons of tests with this

column13: ofCamera with ofFbo

column16: shaders
column17: vflip + different orientation... and this solves as far as i\'ve tested lots of problems we were having with the default vflip in OF since now everything in the core tests for vFlip and does the right thing instead of supposing that the vflip is always active as it was before"'

column10: b'b" the anchor is behaving the same as before
column11: changing it will actually break more projects :) the only thing that changes is that now ofImage generates a quad with the vertices growing in the direction of y so the image looks ok instead of upside down for people coming from 2d OF to ofCamera this also makes more sense since they won\'t expect images to be drawn upside down by default also now you can set the camera to behave like default OF with -y up which you couldn\'t do before"'

column10: b"b' this would be a couple more of ugly global functions like other globals we have
column11: something like ofReverseAnchorsOnVFlip() /ofReverseTexturesOnVFlip() or something like. in my opinion if y is growing upwards everything should behave as default openGL if you want to work with y flipped then you just need to set it when calling setupPerspective or when setting up the camera but adding more global flags for each possible thing that can be reversed when vflip is off would be super confusing not only to use but also the internal logic would be really messed up.'"

column10: b"b' @arturoc I guess though the thing is
column11: is that a change like this has the potential to completely break 0.7.4 projects.  Even  built with OF that other people use. Its a little cruel to not provide a way for people to use 0.8.0 without going through all their source code and changing things in a ton of places
column12: to fit the new model.  I think I would be a lot happier with this change if we had the option to switch it  and then chose whether we release with it on by default
column13: but give the user a one line fix to enable the old behavior if desired.  If we did this how many files would be affected? Just ofTexture? I know the ugly globals are not great but they serve a purpose. ofDisableArb etc its one extra global function but it could make all the difference. '"

column10: b'b\' yes there\\\'s more places where we were by default doing things as if vflipped was active instead of checking
column11: the whole logic for vflip
column12: orientation and handedness was completely broken
column13: for example ofCamera was setting the handedness to right but never setting it back to left and there were several cases like this with orientation
column14: vflip and handedness all over the core
column15: so there\\\'s for sure more things that people were hacking to make them work with ofCamera.  there\\\'s also the thing with orientation which before wasn\\\'t working with ofCamera and now does so people using cameras with different orientations will have hacks in their code to fix that too. for this one it would be a real mess to provide a global to "unfix" it and it\\\'s way hard to fix in people\\\'s projects i think a global like ofDisableArb is more or less ok because it changes the state for something that is logic even if most of the time is only used for allocating one texture. but in this case we would be adding global functions to unfix things which will make the code more difficult to maintain in the future. i can add a global for this particular case
column16: it just affects ofTexture and even if it\\\'ll introduce a really weird logic is only one place. but i don\\\'t think it\\\'s worth given that more things are going to break anyway.\''

b'b" oxKinect kinect id\'s not maintained"'
b'b" This is with Xcode on a mac mini
column11: osx mountain lion. I have two kinects in specific locations. The calibration is set up for where they are
column12: and the settings are loaded for every start of the system. Theoretically
column13: their location should not change with respect to the calibration because they are being identified with the id\'s: for (int i=0; i<2; i++){    kinect[i].close();    kinect[i].init(false
column14: false);    //  (true);    kinect[i].open(i);  } (can\'t set tilt angle because it is not flat on a surface) The problem is that they are not always referring to the proper coordinates as set in the calibration file for kinect[0] and kinect[1]. I am disconnecting them every night (putting my mac mini away) and reconnecting every morning

column10: b"b' Actually just ran into this issue. The sorting is happening and device list is being sorted by serial number correctly.  The issue is that opening via the ID is not opening with the now sorted index but the original bus id ( which is basically the order you plug the kinects in ). So the sorting is actually having no effect.  Here are two cases where I plug in the same two kinects but in a different order.  Notice in the second list device B shows up with id 0 and device A has id 1. The devices are sorted correctly in the device list but calling will produce two different results as it matches against the id and not the index.  So in the second scenario will actually open the second device in the device list and not the first.  I believe this a bug as the whole point of doing the sorting was that calling (0) would always open the same kinect regardless of the order it was enumerated in.  The fix for this should be quite simple: Change: to  '"

b'b" Jason I think i know what it is you are drawing within the update() method.  Did you try to move your  block to the draw() method to see what happens? My bet would be that all is good there. I see this as a feature rather than a bug
column11: since it encourages people to keep OpenGL operations within draw() rather than using update(). Although drawing within update() is perfectly ok normally
column12: this has the implication that there are no default shaders bound. When the draw() method starts
column13: the programmable GL renderer will bind the default shaders. It will then make sure _always_ to have a shader bound during draw(). It doesn\'t do so for performance reasons in update(). Personally
column14: I try to keep all openGL related methods & calls within draw() all these methods have to execute on the main thread
column15: after all and i put all non-openGL methods & calls into update(). By sticking to this principle
column16: i can do multi-threaded work on update()
column17: whilst keeping draw() single-threaded and (OpenGL) thread-safe. "'

column10: b"b' @tgfrerer any idea why it works on MacOS
column11: then?'"

column10: b'b" @bilderbuchi good point! Turns out
column11: as soon as you issue a draw command within update() on any non-RPi platforms
column12: the default shaders get bound.  This doesn\'t happen on RPi
column13: since it uses a special one-fits-all default shader for perfomance reasons (shader swaps are costly on RPi)
column14: and any requests to swap the default shaders get rejected on RPi because there
column15: uniqueshader is set to true. The problem is
column16: when you call any draw operations before the draw loop binds a default shader explicitly
column17: no shader will be bound. One remedy for this would be to call beginDefaultShaders earlier
column18: and explicitly on RPi. Like
column19: when the renderer is set up: @jvcleave
column20: could you insert  into ofGLProgrammableRenderer#L1684 and let me know if that solves the issue?"'

column10: b'b" The works as well as the doing the and in I didn\'t see any performance hit by adding so I think that is my preferred solution as it would keep things consistent when porting existing Desktop apps to the RPi. I know alphaMaskingShaderExample draws in as wellurl  I am going to test a few more things that I think this may solve as well. "'
b'b" Great!  I\'d be for adding beginDefaultShader (at the line I indicated a bit earlier) for Rpi then
column11: following the principle of least surprise
column12: allowing you to render in draw(). You\'re right
column13: there shouldn\'t be any performance hit on Rpi
column14: since the default shader will only get swapped as few times as possible.  Cheers# Tim via phone"'

column10: b"b' @ofTheo
column11: The reason why the destructor is being called in  is because std::exit cleans up any static variables. if Since OFSAptr is static it will get de-allocated by std::exit.  the reason why no destructor is being called in   is that inside the function there are 2 shared pointers
column12: OFSAptr and OFSA. Both have have ownership of testApp(). But since OFSA never goes out of scope
column13: and std::exit will not clean up memory created at runtime
column14: testApp() will never be released. Anyway can we stop using std::exit? It seems very ugly.  What is the reasoning  behind this?'"

column10: b"b' we used std::exit because glut never ends the main loop so the only way to finish the application was that and then have a callback that gets called on exit. with GLFW we have control over the main loop so we can finish it when we detect that the window is closing through glfw_window_should_close(). so yes we should move to that and remove the call to std::exti at least for the glfw window'"

column10: b"b' feature request: allow ofxOscReceiver to send messages (from the same port it receives)'"
b'b\' One thing that is sometimes limiting about the classes (when trying to implement an OSC  model)
column11: is that each side involved in a networking exchange needs to know the other side\\\'s  beforehand. It would be convenient to be able to open an
column12: serving a specific port
column13: and have it reply to whatever clients make requests. At the same time
column14: it\\\'d be nice to be able to write a client such that it only needs to know the server\\\'s
column15: but the server doesn\\\'t need to know anything about the client (e.g. doesn\\\'t need to know beforehand what port to reply to). The client simply makes a request (says "hello") to the server
column16: and the server gets the reply port from the endpoint of the incoming message. But when the client has separate and (as must be the case now)
column17: then each of these will have a different port -client messages received by the server show the port of the client\\\'s sender
column18: and replies back to that same port wouldn\\\'t be seen by its receiver. The server needs to know the client\\\'s receiver port -so why not make it the _same_ as the sender port (in cases when this is desired?). I made a fix (for my own use) for this problem. If you\\\'re interested
column19: you can see it here: url  In summary: I added a method on  . This means a receiver listens for incoming messages (as usual)
column20: but also send messages from the same socket (which means they will show up on the receiving end with the same port number). The is also not tied to send to a single ; it can send to different endpoints on the fly. This functionality is supported by the underlying oscpack library (well
column21: by sockets themselves)
column22: but it\\\'s not exposed in oF. With my change
column23: you can do (in  ): and receive messages as usual

column10: b'b\' I took a look at oscpack
column11: but I don\\\'t see how you can
column12: because it seems the socket has to be bound
column13: in order to get its local endpoint (there is an at the start of  ).  However
column14: of course you can\\\'t bind an ofxOscSender (unless you make a sort of combined
column15: which is essentially what I was suggesting above). Really
column16: I think the easiest thing would be to add and methods to the ofxOscReceiver
column17: that would allow you to send messages without being connected to remote points (a connect could also be added
column18: for convenience when talking to a single point).  If you don\\\'t like the conceptual "contamination"
column19: then add a new class that can both receive and send.  Alternatively
column20: yes
column21: _if_ there was a way to get the local port number that is being used by a connected ofxOscSender and _if_ indeed it works to create an ofxOscReceiver bound to that (shared) port number
column22: then that would be a solution
column23: and would not break the  paradigm by putting "send" methods in a receiver...  It seems to me that if UdpSocket (or OfxOscSender) had a method that called on the underlying socket
column24: I think that would give us the port number.  I don\\\'t know whether binding a Receiver to that port would actually work
column25: although from what you say above
column26: it seems like it should (since ports are now set up to be shared).  I don\\\'t have a  lot of time to look at this right now
column27: but maybe I could quickly try it. By the way
column28: this usage (sending from and receiving on the same socket) is very typical in applications.  (Personally
column29: I like the idea of a single  that can do this.)  If you look at languages like SuperCollider or
column30: they tend to send and receive on the same local port number.  If I send to an ofxOscReceiver from the SuperCollider language
column32: the messages\\\' remote endpoint is port 57120.  If I send OSC messages back from oF to port 57120
column33: the SuperCollider language receives them.  Nice and simple.\''

column10: b'b" I think libopenFrameworks.a is fine.  Basically the issue is that in Xcode if you have a library included as Xcode changes it to in the project settings.  Then if you have a dynamic lib of OpenCV installed in / Xcode decides to link to that one instead of the one you explicitly provided. This causes problems when sharing an executable because the linker most likely won\'t find the dynamic library when running on another machine.  I have seen this issue with libusb as well. "'
b'b" While it wouldn\'t be difficult to make the change in the Xcode project and
column11: the hangup might be in existing user-projects
column12: as they\'d be linking against a now missing static library  . I still think we should use the lib-prefixed filename but I just wanted to mention the user-action required when this is made."'

Perhaps the solution is just to delete the directory?  Or if that directory is required and can\'t live elsewhere
column11: we need to update the makefiles. Anyway
column12: here\'s an example of harmless but annoying makefile spew:  "'

column10: b"b' Hey @bakercp!  as far as I know these files are needed ( they need to be installed on windows and also linux ) they are not libs but support files. I have been trying to keep the libfreenect in ofxKinect in sync with the upstream as close as possible
column11: so renaming them would be a little confusing.  could we make some sort of ignore for this one case?'"

column10: b'b" Absolutely ... I\'d prefer not to rename upstream libs.  I\'ll look into a makefile exclusion. "'
b'b" @ofTheo turns out this is not a problem after all -I thought it was happening across the board
column11: but it\'s only happening with a very specific case in ofSketch.  I\'m closing this for now apologies for the false alarm."'

column10: b'b\' OK.  I figured it out ... ofxKinect was just a symptom
column11: not the problem.  It\\\'s much more specific than I originally thought
column12: but needs a fix anyway.  Basically
column13: the way the makefiles work is that they gather up all of the possible source directories in a project and then apply a set of exclusion filters that include: The problem is that make does not deal well with spaces in paths
column14: so when any subfolder in a project has a space in the folder name any folder name token after a space gets treated as a new folder and is not excluding.  This causes to fail when looking for source files in that folder because the "folder" doesn\\\'t actually exist. So
column15: basically we need to figure out a better way of dealing with the spaces. Anyway
column16: the reason I discovered this was because we include an of distribution (which includes the ofxKinect addon) in the  folder of ofSketch ... but the problem turns out to be slightly more general than that. I\\\'m working on a fix.  Sorry for the extra chatter / false alarm @ofTheo. \''

column14: drivers of some sort need to be installed. CUDA drivers are neither needed for OpenGL nor openFrameworks
column15: CUDA is an Nvidia specific GPGPU api. The trouble with OpenGL 1.1 is that oF never truly supported it. Things like frame buffers
column16: which are not part of OpenGL 1.1
column17: have been part of openFrameworks in the fixed function pipeline for ages
column18: and it wouldn\'t make sense to make it more complex to maintain and extend our renderers just to support a legacy api. I understand and welcome the motivation to (re)use old hardware

column10: b'b" this last commit builds the 32bit and 64bit libs seperately in a subdirectory of _buildroot url  the structure create looks like this: ![screen shot 2014-08-11 at 3 44 54 pm]url  the lipo phase merges the libs from 32bit and 64bit into FAT and then the copy phase copies the includes and lib from FAT into the ofxOpenCv addon lib location.  curious what you think of this approach @bakercp as a good practice for all libs. b'b\' From WWDC 2014
column11: Session 214: View Controller Advancements in iOS8Quote from Bruce Nilo:First
column12: let\\\'s see what we mean here. Basically if I rotate a device in general
column13: that\\\'s all that\\\'s happening. The fact that there\\\'s an animated transform rotation is kind of beside the point. And most of the time your application really doesn\\\'t need to do anything. It\\\'s going to gracefully stretch and do whatever it needs to do as the bounds change. Okay
column14: so what does that mean? Well
column15: you will recall that we have these APIs that have been around for a long time. Well
column16: we\\\'re getting rid of them. And [Applause]-ah
column17: I thought you guys all loved these. So one of the things about these APIs
column18: and I think I\\\'ve been on this stage before saying
column19:
You shouldn\\\'t do layout based on interface orientation. You shouldn\\\'t use these methods to drive your layout." They\\\'re really kind of focused methods. You wanted to use them because you wanted to participate in this rotation event. So now we\\\'ve generalized it. We have this other method called viewWillTransitionToSize:w ithTransitionCoordinator that takes over. So, first of all, all those rotation callbacks can be replaced with this more general notion of viewWillTransitionToSize: withTransitionCoordinator. Where I found the transcript: url \''

column10: b'b" Just want to make clear the importance of supporting MinGW compiler (not necessary with Code::Blocks only
column11: you can use it with Qt Creator and other open source IDE\'s): 1) MSVC doesn\'t support C++11 fully yet. 2) MinGW has no dependency on VCredist libraries. 3) MinGW can compile Windows binaries from Linux. I use this feature in production work
column12: without it I wouldn\'t be able to use openFrameworks at all. 4) MinGW is the only open source compiler for Windows. Importance of being open is the reason why we have Microsoft Open Technologies group

column12: 2013. Code::Blocks ships with it. MinGW-w64 is an alternative project that includes several new APIs (such as DirectShow) and provides 64-bit support. It is maintained and used by MSYS2. It can target 32-bit binaries from 32-bit machines or both 32 and 64-bit from 64-bit machines."'

column10: b'b" thank\'s it\'s work"'
b"b' removes statics and globals. adds multiwindow'"
b'b" This removes almost all statics
column11: singletons and global calls (like ofPushMatrix
column12: ofGetWidth...) from the core
column13: at least form the graphics and core events pipeline. To do that
column14: the following function based apis have been transformed into classes:ofGraphics3dofBitmapFontofEvents -while keeping the api totally backwards compatible. Windows now contain their own renderer and core events instance and notify that instead of the global one. Each renderer contains it\'s own ofGraphics3d and ofBitmapFont
column15: which avoids singletons allowing multiwindow or multicontext even on different threads if everything is done through a explicit renderer. There\'s a new class ofMainLoop which is the only singleton in the rendering pipeline and is responsible of creating new windows and calling them in a loop if the window doesn\'t provide it\'s own loop as is the case of glut
column16: android and iphone. the old syntax to create windows is still working but there\'s a new way which is the preferred one: where one can pass width
column17: height and window mode (windowed
column18: fullscreen...) to the settings like: or: there\'s also specializations of the window settings like: or  egl
column19: iOS and android should have their own window settings class although that\'s not implemented yet. the EGL and iOS windows indeed still need to be refactored to use the new api. To use multiwindow the syntax is: and simpler using c++11: There\'s also a way of creating a window without associated app and just bind some of it\'s events to an existing app. There\'s a couple of examples showing both cases in the events folder. Also every class that can be drawn or binded can be called the traditional way like: or through a renderer like: which allows to use different gl contexts or even windows from different threads for example. this api is still experimental but there\'s an example on how to use it in "'

column10: b'b" @underdoeg no
column11: it\'s completely compatible with old projects. the main loop is the only singleton and internally it sets the current window event as it\'s events and thus as global: although you could create your own mainLoop in the main function in order to for example run 2 or more mainLoops with their windows in different threads in which case the functions in ofAppRunner
column12: ofEvents
column13: ofGraphics and of3dGraphics and the draw and bind methods of most classes won\'t work and everything needs to be called trough the window
column14: it\'s renderer and events as it\'s demoed in the example in devApps. @ofTheo i\'ve tested all the examples and all are working as they used to. we still need to port the iOS and EGL windows to the new api but the changes should be pretty straight forward:setupOpenGL -initializeWindow() dissappears and whatever was done in that function should be done at the end of setupadd events() and renderer() methods that return the internal window ofCoreEvents and renderer
column15: windows shouldn\'t call any of... function anymore and instead call their own events and rendererthe ofGLReadyCallback introduced in 0.8 disappears
column16: windows now just need to call setup on it\'s own renderer whenever the GL context is readyrunAppWithinifinteLoop disappearsthere\'s some static functions that need to be implemented for each window class:  static void loop(){}; // starts the loop in case the window provides one
column17: like with glut
column18: iOS  static bool doesLoop(){ return false; } // true if the window provides it\'s own loop like glut
column19: iOS...  static bool allowsMultiWindow(){ return true; } static bool needsPolling(){ return true; } // if there\'s a specific call that needs to be called to retrieve events
column20: like with glfw  static void pollEvents(){ glfwPollEvents(); }  // the event polling function
column21: this is the one in GLFW apart from that the only code that i\'ve changed without testing yet and will probably break is the readback of the screen in OpenGL ES which is now in the renderers. in general testing iOS which i haven\'t tested and would be good to do some testing with old projects as it\'s possible that something has changed."'

column10: b"b' Looked a bit more into this today .. The problem seems to be padding on the U and V planes. I am checking the strides of the planes with  and for the Y plane I get 860 but for the U and V planes I get 432 for both of them instead of 430. This seems to be related to the divisible by 4 principle of gstreamer that was mentioned in the initial forum [thread]url  . Is there any way to account for this padding ? I can see that the setFromAlignedPixels uses the 1st plane for the stride and I was wondering what would be the best way to deal with this right now..'"

b"b' i think the fastest way to do this would be by having a padding or stride parameter in ofPixels so ofTexture coul\\xc3\\xb1d take that into account and use the correct glPixelStorei to upload without having to make any copies in ram'"

b'b" I got similar issues but somehow different and made some tests. My testsetup consist of archlinux with gstreamer 1.6 and latest of master. The same applies to Ubuntu 14.04 with gstreamer 1.2.My testApp consists of the ProgammableRenderer and an ofVideoPlayer with pixelFormat set to OF_PIXELS_NATIVE. My Test video is h264 e.g. i420.With a resolution of 1280x720 I get the correct video played:![screenshot from 2015-10-19 21-05-14]url With a resolution of 1278x720 and 1282x720 i get this:![screenshot from 2015-10-19 21-05-22]url I made process_sample a bit more verbose and became for the stock video: and for the faulty displayed video (1278x720): and (1282x720): It seems that it doesn\'t matter if the stride of the y plane is a multiple of the u and v planes or not. In these cases url always gets taken. I had a look at url  and it seems to do the right thing. Cutting of the extra padding bytes. I have no idea how the planes are mapped in memory. Where does the upload to Texture happen?Pinging @arturoc In addition:When converting the same video with ffmpeg to 900x300 i get a green videoframe and run into (I\'m not sure whether this also happens on ubuntu 14.04 with a previous of version) To give credit for the testvideo: url  brokchrd (loop) by beeple"'
b'b" mmh
column11: ok we probably should have some kind of padding attribute in ofPixels so we can add that in the texture when uploading the data otherwise we would need to make copies of all the planes and then stitch them together in the frame call back which would be pretty slow. this is kind of complex so it won\'t get fixed for 0.9 but i\'m milestoning it for next release and will take a look when 0.9 is done"'

column10: b'b" This PR supersedes all existing Apothecary Poco PRs. The Apothecary formulae are now in the master branch.  This PR will only include core code changes and ultimately static libs and new headers. For now

column10: b'b" i think we could have something like or then you can have 2 ofCairoRenderer in your application and switch between them. the main difference is that this way is a setup call which sets the initial parameters to work with an external context and not rely on any initial settings. also that the context won\'t change during the whole life of the renderer which makes it easier to maintain."'

column10: b'b" i\'d say it doesn\'t matter but relying on that seems really brittle. i\'m doing it like that cause the main loop is the only global object now and although it\'s not correct to do any global call from the window setup it might be that someone tries to do it which would crash if there\'s no window yet. i\'m looking at the code but don\'t really get why you need it to happen in that specific order?"'

b"b' @arturocmy issue is that im trying reuse the same ofAppiOSWindow between different ofMainLoops.the correct way would be to destroy the ofAppiOSWindow and create a new one every time a new ofMainLoop is created. the issue with this is that ofAppiOSWindow holds some global state settings like
column11: a flag if to use retina scalea flag if to use anti-aliasing etc.  these are settings you most likely only want to set once in  when creating the ofAppiOSWindow for the very first time. the issue is that these are global settings but they sit inside ofAppiOSWindow and when the window is destroyed
column12: those settings are lost...  anyway
column13: i think the solution is that ofxiOS needs to create some global functions for storing these settings which can then be accesses via ofAppiOSWindow
column14: so they never get reset and when a new ofAppiOSWindow is created
column15: it can launch with these global settings. will get a PR together for this approach to review.'"

b"b' ofxOpenCv textures not drawing with Programmable Renderer. '"

b"b' OS X 10.10 current master.  Currently trying to debug this.But if you run the openCvExample and set the renderer in main: You will only see the video texture and not the opencv textures.  Also if you try and load the data into a texture to draw it externally the texture is drawn red. Printing out the textures internal format shows it to be 6403 which in hex is 0x1903 = GL_RED  If I switch it back to the non programmable renderer it shows the format to be 6409 ( GL_LUMINANCE )  ![screen shot 2015-09-18 at 12 50 50 pm]url '"

b'b" This might be because GL_LUMINANCE was deprecated in OpenGL with the advent of 3.2.  GL_RED is traditionally the correct texture type to take up its place. Most probably the shader used to render the texture is not recognising it properly. I can look into it once I\'m on a proper computer. "'

b"b' you need to allocate the texture using the pixels directly instead of passing any GL enum like: then ofTexture will do the right thing. to solve the red texture you can call: i though all these were already fixed'"
b'b" that fixes it
column11: i remember now that i started fixing it but didn\'t because the structure is pretty convoluted. i\'ve added a couple of methods that allocate the corresponding texture and pixels on each image type. there\'s some really weird things like the ofPixels in the base image that is then not used in the short and float images. we should switch or at least include ofxCv for next release"'

column10: b"b' @arturoc oh great! just tested this with both the regular and programmable renderer. both work fine now in terms of drawing the cv images.  however in the programmable renderer the texture allocated from () is still showing up red.  to reproduce:   '"
b"b' ps: agree on having a more modern CV implementation. ofxOpenCv is about as legacy as it gets ( though still pretty useful for what it covers ) '"
b'b" yes that can\'t be fixed just like that
column11: there\'s no LUMINANCE target in GL 3+ so you always have to use GL_RED. the swizzles thing tells the shaders that r -"'

column10: b"b' you can do: in setup and that will make the image show as grayscale'"

b'b" hmm if I do:  it still shows red. same with:  assuming this can be fixed for 1.0 to 3.2 compatibility couldn\'t we do something inside of ofTexture::loadData that would do the swizzle automatically if the incoming target is a single channel?  or maybe better do this at the default shader level?"'
b"b' hmm if I do: then it comes through fine. looks like something with loadData? '"

b"b' Is this something like a 0.9.1 release or a 0.10.0 idea. I am open to looking into updating the openCV implementation since it might actually cover some of the other issues that occasionally get brought up. I am curious about how their videoWriter compares to ffmpegs which has been slightly a PITA to work with. '"

b'b" the auto allocation in ofTexture just uses the passed format as internal format which is not very correct and won\'t always work. it\'s kind of a workaround and the only way to ensure that a texture will do the right thing is to allocate it first and then load data onto it.  there\'s even a todo comment in that part of the code: which can more or less be done but won\'t always work. i\'ve added some checks when calling loadData with ofPixels so it allocates from that instead of trying to pass the glFormat as internal but when loading data from raw memory it\'ll still fail. i\'ve also added a check on allocate with ofPixels so if the pixel format of the pixels is gray or gray alpha then it auto enables the RG->RGBA swizzles."'

column10: b'b\' The up-vector is a vector that tells the camera where "up" is.  Your camera sits on the y-axis and points forward. To help getting the up-vector I like to look at my right hand
column11: and point the index finger in direction
column12: then push the thumb up.  That\\\'s your up-vector. My guess is that your up-vector should be something like (0
column15: because if you\\\'re pointing straight down
column16: your thumb would point forward
column17: thus in -z. By default
column18: the up-vector is
column19: meaning the camera points straight ahead. If you set the camera on the y-axis
column20: it can\\\'t calculate an unambiguous because the ray it points along and the up-vector are essentially the same. \''

column10: b'b" i\'m testing this just in case and the problem is just what @tgfrerer is describing
column11: you have the up vector parallel to the lookAt one which gives an ambiguous orientation and so the calculation gives an indeterminate result. testing with: does the correct thing."'

column10: b"b' do we handle header paths (for addons) right on osx?'"
b'b\' sorry for the empty issue :) via url  cc @sterlingcrispin  it seems like there are potentially two issues with header paths on xcode: (a) we have always search user paths set to true
column11: in this case
column12: a header from the user path was being chosen over a header from a framework. setting it to false fixed this issue.  "Specifies whether the compiler searches for headers in the project directory before searching system directories. This build setting is used only with GCC 4.0 and later." this doesn\\\'t seem like a good idea to me and can lead to gnarly / hard to compile issues. (b) we are putting addon headers in HEADER_SEARCH_PATHS but there is also USER_HEADER_SEARCH_PATHS url  url  it seems like one is for type headers and the other is for type headers....  It\\\'s not clear if we are using the right one.\''

column10: b'b\' for sure I have seen issues similar to the one with ofxOpenVDB with conflicting header includes (ie
column11: things that have the same name as system headers).  I\\\'m of the opinion that this flag should be set to no and not yes in the template: I think it was inadertantly set to yes because it sounds really helpful "always look at user paths"  sure!  go for it! but really
column12: it\\\'s kind of dangerous
column13: because it really means "always look at user paths FIRST" and the sort of compile errors you get from choosing a user header over a system header can give you massive headaches
column14: etc. \''

column10: b'b" i think that\'s probably just the default. if it\'s disabled won\'t we get the opposite problem? trying to include a use header that has the same name and relative path to a system one will include the system one instead? If we\'ve really changed this setting when creating the project then lets turn it off but if it\'s the default i\'d leave it like it is i\'ve also reported in the openvdb addon issue which would be the way to fix this without having to change this setting"'
b'b" ah right I can see the opposite problem.... I will dig around some more but it seems like we\'ve had this setting for a while now."'
b'b\' for more info
column11: here\\\'s the quick help entry on this setting
column12: which explains it in more detail:  If enabled both #include -style and #include "header.h"-style directives will search the paths in "User Header Search Paths" before "Header Search Paths"
column13: with the consequence that user headers (such as your own String.h header) would have precedence over system headers when using #include . This is done using the -iquote flag for the paths provided in "User Header Search Paths". If disabled and your compiler fully supports separate user paths
column14: user headers will only be accessible with #include "header.h"-style preprocessor directives.  For backwards compatibility reasons
column15: this setting is enabled by default
column16: but disabling it is strongly recommended. [ALWAYS_SEARCH_USER_PATHS]\''

column10: b"b' Move constructors: noexcept missing -> issue with STL container'"
b'b" Hi
column11: I\'ve just came across the issue that the c++ STL standard containers require the move  in member objects to be \'noexcept\' to allow move operations. The compiler might be clever in some cases but this is not guaranteed. I checked the oF sources and saw that none of the move constructors and assignements for containers (like ofPixels or ofImage) are noexcept. I made a little test program to show that in a vector of ofPixels
column12: the pixel data is copied for reallocations instead of being moved. What do you think about adding noexcept? Are there any drawbacks? See copy_ for the behaviour of oF containers inside a vector and compare it with move_
column13: where I made a class Foo with a noexcept move constructor. (Try to delete \'noexcept\' and see how vector will do copies instead.) Links: url url  [copy_vs_]url "'

column10: b'b" no
column11: just didn\'t knew about this
column12: we don\'t throw exceptions anyway so marking the move constructors as no except would be great if that enables classes to be moved into containers. do you want to send a PR? i think this is something that could go into 0.9.4 since there\'s been several fixes for move constructors in the patch versions of 0.9.x so if you do send a PR please do it against the 0.9.4 branch and i\'ll merge it later into master"'
