b"b' ofFile::open() ALWAYS calls ofToDataPath()'"
b"b' This makes many (most?) ofFile functions fail if bRelativeToData is false
column11: such as doesFileExist()
column12: copyFromTo()
column13: removeFile() etc.'"

column10: b"b' I removed the ofToDataPath() from open() and it seemed to my calls using bRelativeToData = false and it fixed most of my issues.  The only side effect I noticed was ofShader::load() (which uses ofBufferFromFile which uses ofFile) now needs paths local to CWD instead of to the data directory.  I expect other classes using ofBufferFromFile() or ofFile directly will have the same issue.'"
b"b' seems like the correct thing to do would be to check if bRelativeToDataPath is true and only then use ofToDataPath'"

b'b" The ofFile static functions that accept this flag conditionally callofToDataPath() based on the flag.  The only reason this didn\'t breakeverything by calling ofToDataPath() TWICE is  because that function makesan attempt to check if the path passed in is already relative to the datadirectory. Passing the flag through seems like the right choice but that meanschanging every single function that uses ofFile objects
column11: and as such manythat use ofBuffer objects.  Not a simple fix.  Many opportunities forchanges in behavior. On Sunday

column10: b'b\' This is a fairly nuanced issue. From what I understand the confusion / issue is the lack of data path controls within ofFile and by extension the classes that use it.  The overides for data path in the static ofFile methods are somewhat the exception and not the rule.  To add those overides for all file loading calls would be a huge change to OF and as Arturo suggested it is not really needed when you can just get rid of the data path prefix globally with ofSetDataPath("");  If this doesn\\\'t solve the issue you have run into please open a new issue that explains the bug.  The title of this issue is actually intentional and not a bug :) Also OF is a friendly community
column11: so please try and be friendly here.  Swearing and asking for people to be shot isn\\\'t a friendly or professional way to communicate. \''

b'b" I am going to reopen this; I finally found some time to really look into it and it still is an issue.  When you launch several short-lived ofThreads too suddenly (i.e. spawn a few threads in a single frame)
column11: sometimes the thread gets in a weird state.  I have an example demonstrating the issue [here]url  I have seen the issue both on OSX and windows.  If you run the code above
column12: you will see printouts like this:   every few seconds. This is as far as I got with this
column13: basically the thread object is done (and it executed fine) but the std::thread itself is in a weird state
column14: so if you try to delete it it leads to crash.  You can modify the macro and set it to false to see how it doesn\'t happen with an alternative implementation.  I think it is related to the way the ofThread is launched with :  interacting with the  call in weird ways as you can see [here]url  but I am unsure of what the difference really is.  This is a pretty big stability problem for one of my addons; I worked around the problem by creating a simplified ofThread-like class that works 100% ( left it running for weeks ). You can see this alternate ofThread class [here]url  "'

column10: b'b" if you change to the way you do it then it doesn\'t crash?  also opening a lot of threads in a short period of time doesn\'t sound like a good idea
column11: since it\'s a really expensive operation
column12: not saying we shouldn\'t fix this because of that
column13: this is clearly a bug
column14: but if you need to use several threads in an application you probably want to create a pool of threads and send tasks to then instead or simply use std::async which should use a pool of threads behind the scenes"'

column10: b'b\' No
column11: changing the example to doesn\\\'t make it crash.  Playing a bit more with the example
column12: the cause seems to be the from within the thread.  The original reason for this issue caused the app to crash bc sometimes fails on very short threads. Catching the exception around just hides away the issue temporarily
column13: as when the fails
column14: the thread remains "bugged" and can\\\'t be deleted (I haven\\\'t found a way to do so without a crash). You can at least detect when this happened by checking the if the thread ID is valid (see [here]url The issue seems partly caused because detach() is called from within the thread itself; if I call detach right away from the main thread after creating it
column15: the problem disappears that\\\'s the main difference in my alternative ofThread implementation [here]url  I\\\'ve been searching for docs on to confirm if its allowed to use it from within the thread
column16: or some advice on where should it be called from
column17: but I found nothing about it \\xe2\\x80\\x93 although all the examples I come across seem to use from the main thread.  It seems everything is easier if you to know what you will do with the thread before you spawn it (and I mean "what will you do" in terms of cleanup strategy; will you join it or will you detach it?). We added in the first place (#2506) bc if the user doesn\\\'t explicitly on the ofThread object from the main thread
column18: ofThread ends up leaking resources and those add up leading to an inability to spawn threads. Detaching is currently almost the very last thing the ofThread does. We can not really delay it any further
column19: and if your is very short lived
column20: the issue will to happen from time to time if we blindly as we currently do. My current solution only works for me because I know beforehand that I will not be joining the thread I\\\'m spawning; thus I can afford to detach it safely from the main thread as soon as I spawn it.  As it seems detaching from the main thread rises no issue
column21: I wonder if an ofThread API change enforcing the user to spawn the thread explicitly stating a cleanup strategy would be to ask too much for the user because doing so would solve the problem.  I could see something along the lines of  ; if we know what the user expects to do from the thread (i.e. no plans to join it) then we can detach it right away from the main thread from startThread() (as the user guarantees  will not  join the thread). In the other case
column22: if the user starts a thread telling ofThread that  plans to join the thread
column23: we can issue detect a broken promise and issue warning if the threadedFunction() exits and the method hasn\\\'t been called (i.e. the user forgot to join the thread)
column24: reminding the user about the resource leak. Either way I think we should not automatically from the thread itself as it can fail under partly unclear circumstances (how short-lived is too short for a thread to fail  ?).  This may be a lot to ask for the users but I believe this will also make the users more aware about the internals of threads and general app architecture
column25: which I would argue is beneficial. I think adding an example demonstrating the two cases would also make things much more clear.  We should probably leave the current API as it is with unchanged behaviour for backwards compatibility
column26: and add two alternative spawn methods i.e. and for more advanced users who have a clear idea on what their thread will do.  PD: Yes the overhead on this example is ludicrous but I merely built it to be able to reproduce the issue. I have a centralised queue that limits on how many requests (i.e. threads) can happen per frame
column27: but because I also have other threads spawning across other areas of the app (and the modules aren\\\'t really aware of each other)
column28: the issue still arises from time to time when a few spawn too "close" to each other.  \''

column10: b"b' yeah saw this yesterday what happened is that getColor(int) has always worked the way it did before this fix. when we introduced ofPixels we were more used to work directly with an array of unsigned char so getColor just received the index in the raw array that was usually calculated with getPixelIndex or just iterating with a for loop using +=4 after using ofPixels for a while and using iterators that can jump to the exact position of every pixel it seems more correct that getColor received the pixel index rather than the index in the raw array. not sure what to do:should we go back to the previous version? change getPixelIndex to return the pixel index as in number of pixels rather than index in the raw array?perhaps we can add a getRawPixelIndex getColorAtRawIndex (or something like that) revert this change and deprecate the old methods?'"
b'b" i have not yet fully contemplated the iterative elegance described above
column11: but suggest that keeping a working getColor(x
column12: y) would be a good way bridging the oldstyle scary array index calculations with the new concept of implementing iterators. getColor() is ineffective and a bit slow but i use it a lot for non-realtime work as it hides the array index calculus. wouldn\'t a change in the general approach break a lot of people\'s code?"'

column10: b'b" yeah totally that\'s why i was suggesting to add new methods with a more descriptive name and keep the old ones with the exact same behavior but deprecated"'

To me the way it works now does seem correct ( for index based lookup ). I think we are just missing a ofPixels::getNumPixels() and a fix for 2D lookup.  But maybe I don\'t completely understand the current issue? :) "'

b"b' Fix #5512 Give icosahedron normals & texcoords'"
b"b' In the previous version
column11: icosphere() could be used to produce icosahedrons with normals and texture coordinates
column12: while  icosahedron() would produce just the faces with missing normals and texture coordinates.  The dependency between icosphere and icosahedron has been reversed
column13: and icosahedron() now provides normals and texture  coordinates.'"

column10: b"b' Nice work.  Confirmed working on master w/ macOS.'"

b"b' that looks good but i think the normals should be flat for an icosahedron and smooth for an icosphere. perhaps there should be a common private function for icosphere and icosahedron for the geometry and then each would add the correct normals. otherwise the faces look strange when seen with lighting'"

column11: which would duplicate vertices to get the expected non-smooth icosahedron? Such method could be used with other primitives like cylinder or any random mesh.'"

b"b' windowMode not being passed on to ofAppGLFWWindow'"

b'b" I discovered that the windowMode variable in  is always OF_WINDOW because of the constructor [setting it to that]url  by default but the variable is never changed by the settings from ofBaseWindow(?). Many instances of the code work with  (which works) some only use the local windowMode variable (which does not work because its always OF_WINDOW). See f.e.: url url Because of that many functions are basically broken for OF_FULLSCREEN and OF_GAME_MODE.  I would fix it by having  assigned to the local windowMode variable in the setup and then from there on only use windowMode throughout the rest of the code. Before I do that and make a pull request I wanted to ask here first though if that is the proper approach for OF or not
column11: maybe there is a different intention there that I\'m missing."'

column10: b'b" Okay the orientation issue now doesn\'t seem related.  Something since I last checked means it happens regardless of ofSetOrientation calls. All you need to do now to kill the screen on iOS is create and try and clear an FBO in ofApp::setup Put this in ofApp::setup on iOS   My guess is that because the rendering / render surfaced isn\'t fully setup somehow at the time ofApp::setup is called when Fbo::end is called it doesn\'t correctly restore the matrix / surface etc to the correct setting. Moving iOS\'s setup call to the first time it renders fixes it but causes other issues. Changing this line:  url to:  Fixes the issue. I am going to put a PR in with this fix
column11: so others can test.  There may be a more elegant fix though. Pinging @danoli3  "'

column10: b"b' Bugfix sound buffer resampler'"
b'b" Hi there
column11: my first contribution... Last year I worked with @roymacdonald Roy McDonald\'s ofSoundObjects and discovered a problem when running his example-soundPlayerObject: url The example loops an audio file and has a speed control. I generate a short stereo tone wave file with a different frequency for each channel but an exact number of wavelengths. When scrubbing the speed there were lots of clicks and sometimes it would crash.  I eventually found this issue here and managed to fix it. There are still problems for very short files (<512 samples) but this is much more robust. Would love to see this in as I\'m looking forward to getting involved. David Fee"'

column10: b"b' hey @dfeeuh great that you are contributing here and getting used to git. :) There are a few problems
column11: first I think that you made the changes on top of the master branch but then you made the pull request on top of the patch-release branch (the patch-release is the default but you should make the PR on top of the master). I am not sure if you can change this or if you need to make a new PR. When doing the PR there are some dropdown menus in the top where you chose to which branch you are making the PR. This is why there are all this commits that dont belong to you and I think that it will be a problem.  then
column12: in your code there are a lot of new lines
column13: try to comment this more as it is quite hard to get to understand what you are doing
column14: thus it makes it hard to get it approved for merging. I will take a deeper view into your code and let you know. best'"

b"b' I am facing the same errors with the 2019 nightly version from the website.  There are a few things which bothers me. column10: b'b" when loading shaders from source in gl 3+ there\'s an extra step that needs to be done to bind the default attribute locations by calling  This is done so in case you don\'t want to use the default OF attribtues and uniforms for position
column11: normal
column12: color
column13: matrices... you can set your own. when loading we do it by default but if you are using the more manual we understand that you want to explicitly indicate every step.  This could be a parameter to though or even a second method like  "'

column12: turns out it was because the shader was setupFromSource :) more manual we understand that you want to explicitly indicate every step. yes this makes a lot of sense. yes making this more transparent could help. an argument to sounds good.  One question though

column10: b'b" it\'s just how opengl works
column11: attributes get a fixed location when linking. if you don\'t provide one before
column12: at link time the linker assigns each attribute a location that can\'t be changed afterwards"'
